I would have nothing evaluated in global scope. Keep it all in functions.

But no need to put it in a module. You can just have a top-level script that `include`s a bunch of function definitions and then calls `main`.

Use `Exfiltrator.jl` to stay sane while debugging inside functions.

Most important thing is to use `Manifest.toml` and make sure that you have `Pkg.activate(".")` and `instantiate` somewhere.

text: I think I could see either one working. For example, you could have a module with a function `replicate(path)` and it writes everything to the path (results, figures, etc.). That is geared towards reproducibility. For reproducibility, you probably want to expose the functionality such that it can be used with new data and adapted to new similar applications. In that case it might work by modifying scripts or by using exported functionality (e.g., pass new data, select different features).

text: A module is just a namespace. Main for example is a default module. Base is also a module. A package is just a module that is meant to be shared and such. A manifest file allows Julia to know what dependencies a module needs in order to obtain and set up the environment.

If you want anyone else to run your code ever, or even if you want to run julia code a few months from now, you need a `Manifest.toml`. Bascially, the folder structure of

```Project.toml
Manifest.toml
src/```
should exist no matter what you are doing. The only difference is that if your code is an "end-use" code , like data analysis, then you don't need to wrap it in a `module`.

text:
A package is downloaded and compiled. Any time that exact version is required it will use the local version. If it needs a different version it will do the same and get that different version and compile it. It is smart (unlike R) and will not keep extra copies.

If you use :vscode: you can omit the `julia --proj` and such as many of the environment commands are inferred based on the project open and such.

text: Definetely use an (unregistered) package with a Manifest checked into source code control. It is very lightweight and makes things reproducible. You can generate it with PkgTemplates.jl without any hassle. And it even makes sense to write simple unit tests as you go, just to avoid mistakes that might otherwise set you back.
